title: First irregular discharge
vignette: A man notices an unusual bodily emission once after an illness.

options.text: One sighting alone does not render him a emission case; wait and see.
Any abnormal discharge imparts contamination immediately.

title: Second sighting same day
vignette: Later that afternoon, a second emission occurs.

options.text: Two sightings establish emission case status and require counting.
Only if seen on separate days does it count.

title: Discharge caused by exertion
vignette: Heavy lifting seems to trigger the emission each time.

options.text: If due to exertion, he remains clean.
Cause doesn't matter; repeated emissions create contamination.

title: Touching food while contaminated
vignette: Before realizing his status, he handled baskets of produce.

options.text: The food becomes first-degree contaminated and must be discarded.
Only if he actually felt unwell at the time would it transmit.

title: Seat contamination
vignette: He sat on a stone bench in the town square during his emission period.

options.text: Anything he sits on becomes a source of contamination.
Public benches remain clean to avoid communal hardship.

title: Questionable third sighting
vignette: A small stain may or may not be a new discharge.

options.text: Treat doubt as a full sighting and continue counting.
Ignore uncertain stains and assume no new emission.

title: Submersion before sunset
vignette: He completes his seven days and immerses just before nightfall.

options.text: Submersion counts even minutes before sunset.
Better to wait until morning to be sure.

title: Carrying objects while contaminated
vignette: During the counting days he carries packages for work.

options.text: Objects he carries become contaminated regardless.
Only items he directly touches are affected, not what he merely moves.

title: Entering the central complex area
vignette: He accidentally steps onto the central complex Mount while still a emission case.

options.text: He must bring a sin offering once cleaned.
Since it was an accident, apology suffices.

title: Recontamination during count
vignette: On day five he experiences another emission.

options.text: The count resets from the beginning after each new sighting.
Only three consecutive days restart the count.

title: Shared riding saddle
vignette: A friend unknowingly uses his saddle soon after he rode it.

options.text: Anything he sits or lies on transmits contamination to others.
Transmission requires direct contact with fluids, not just seating.

title: Bodily spit contact
vignette: While talking, droplets from his mouth land on a neighbor's coat.

options.text: Spit from a emission case conveys contamination and requires washing.
Such minor spray is negligible and ignored.

title: Reusing contaminated clothing
vignette: After recovery he wants to keep the garments worn during contamination.

options.text: They can be laundered and reused normally.
Better to burn them to remove any doubt.

title: Touching sacred foods
vignette: He helps prepare offerings despite still counting days.

options.text: A emission case must avoid donated portion and holy foods entirely.
He may assist if careful not to defile them directly.

title: Final purification offering
vignette: After submersion he delays bringing the required sacrifice.

options.text: He remains contaminated until the offering is brought.
Submersion alone suffices; the sacrifice may come later.
